text: <@U302R1EAE|dhood> has joined the channel
<@U302V6F8A|edwardaux> has joined the channel

Howdy team... I'm looking to create a class that will need to be referenced by many activities - let's call it `MyAPIManager`. This API manager might have some state that needs to be maintained (eg. the current session identifier). Now, the really easy thing to do is create a singleton and reference it everywhere as `MyAPIManager.getInstance()`, however, I'm coming from the iOS world where singletons are really frowned on and dependencies are exposed explicitly and we'd pass a reference to the object into each view controller.  As a pattern, I'm really happy with moving away from singletons. It makes testing and reasoning about behaviour much much easier.

However, in the Android world, a lot of the official documentation still talks about using singletons (or putting the object into a subclass of `Application`).  Is there a particular pattern (or convention) that is being adopted in the Android community for passing an object around between activities (I know I can make the API manager conform to `Parcelable`, but I'm not sure if that is the current/best style for passing objects around to avoid singletons).

I understand that this is probably one of those topics where 10 devs will give 10 different answers, but I'm curious as to what other patterns I can explore or are being actively promoted to make dependencies more explicit.  Any thoughts?
Singletons are looked down upon because they are often abused
But case like that is justified imo, check out enum singletons
<@U302V6F8A> Short answer: DI. If, for some reason, you don't have DI in you app, singleton is kind of inevitable.
the reason why official documentation if full of bad practices is that Google didn't really care about code quality until the last year.
Still, we're talking about keeping a global state, singleton is kindnof inevitable here too
that's single instance, not singleton
I believe that a single instance living through the whole app life cycle is a singleton
yeah, I don’t mind having a single instance (that gets passed around). I just don’t like having a singleton.
<@U0QD0R2LS> so, something like Dagger for DI?
that seems to be the goto for DI, as far as I can tell
yes, Dagger is a standard, but requires some effort, it won't be easy
it's getting easier to get it with all that tutorials and starter packs in place, tho

<@U0548MM6B>  the difference is bigger than just number of instances. It's about the way you build your architecture. Singleton is anti-pattern:
1) violates SRP
2) invisible dependency
3) untestable
4) holds state

only last point is common for singleton and single instance.
if I get it right, <@U302V6F8A> is not debating the need of state itself, more how to deliver it to consumers in a proper way.

<@U0QD0R2LS> I get what you mean, tho I wouldn’t agree it violates the single responsibility principle, since the pattern in itself can’t do that, that is up to you. But by injecting the dependency everywhere what you are doing is basically using a singleton, you’re just abstracting it away and using the DI pattern to pass it instead of just getting an instance.

text: Let's move this to <#C04PLQMUM|hangout>

hey gurus… in Swift and Kotlin, we have the ability to specify a type that looks like:

```
enum Result<T> {
	case success(T)
	case error(Error)
}
```

and use it like: `Result<String>` and know that I'll either get back a String or an Error (it can only be one or the other, never both and never neither). Is there a similar construct that we can use in modern-Java?  Last I checked, Java's enum doesn't have the capability to support associated values. Thoughts?

I guess throwing an exception may work, except that I’d like to invoke an asynch callback method with the result. Alternatively, I guess I could pass an object that has two methods that could be called (one for success and one for error).
I think a 2-method callback makes sense
I’ve also seen a result object that has an error field which you need to check
but that’s fugly IMO
yeah, I’m really trying to avoid passing two objects and having the caller know about when to use one vs the other. I can live with the two method callback… just exploring patterns
<@U302V6F8A> How about Rx?

definitely an option. I’ve been doing a bunch of Rx/RAC stuff in my iOS work recently… hence my desire to head towards a more monadic approach with the Result object. just curious if there was a more idiomatic Java language construct that I could use rather than having to pull in Rx (or functionaljava)
Hmmm with current state I don't think you can do it elegantly with pure Java in Android (Java 7)
But I think you can achieve something like that with Java 8's stream API
